description: Fibroid tumors, also known as uterine fibroids, are noncancerous growths in the uterus. They are common in women of reproductive age and can vary in size. Symptoms can include heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain, and pressure.

name: Farmer's Lung
description: Farmer's lung is a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by inhaling organic dust, such as moldy hay or grain, leading to inflammation in the lungs. It is common among individuals who work with farming materials.
treatment: Avoidance of exposure to triggering substances
preventive_measures: Using protective equipment when handling organic materials
Regular medical check-ups for those at risk

name: Filariasis
description: Filariasis is a parasitic infection caused by thread-like worms transmitted through mosquito bites. It can lead to swelling and thickening of the skin, most commonly affecting the legs, groin, and genitals (elephantiasis).
symptoms: Swelling and pain in the limbs
Thickening and hardening of the skin
preventive_measures: Anti-parasitic drug treatments in endemic areas

name: Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)
description: FSGS is a kidney disease characterized by scarring (sclerosis) in some parts of the glomeruli, the filtering units of the kidney. It can lead to proteinuria (excess protein in the urine), reduced kidney function, and kidney failure.
symptoms: Swelling in the legs, ankles, and feet

name: Fluoride Poisoning
description: Fluoride poisoning occurs when excessive fluoride is ingested, typically through overuse of fluoride-containing products or contaminated water. Acute poisoning can lead to symptoms ranging from mild to severe, depending on the amount consumed.
symptoms: Severe poisoning can cause seizures and cardiac arrest
preventive_measures: Monitoring fluoride levels in drinking water
Proper dosing of fluoride supplements in children

name: Focal Dystonia
description: Focal dystonia is a movement disorder where a specific part of the body experiences involuntary muscle contractions, leading to abnormal postures or movements. It can affect different parts of the body, such as the neck, eyelids, or hand.
symptoms: Pain or discomfort in the affected area
treatment: Botulinum toxin injections to relax muscles
preventive_measures: Physical therapy to improve motor function

name: Focal Epilepsy
description: Focal epilepsy refers to a type of epilepsy where seizures originate in one specific part of the brain. It can cause a variety of symptoms depending on the area of the brain involved, such as changes in sensation, movement, or awareness.
symptoms: Seizures originating in one part of the body

name: Fournier's Gangrene
description: Fournier's gangrene is a rare, life-threatening soft tissue infection that affects the genital, perineal, and perianal regions. It often involves both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria and progresses rapidly, leading to tissue necrosis.
symptoms: Severe pain in the genital or perineal area
treatment: Supportive care including fluids and pain management
preventive_measures: Timely treatment of underlying conditions such as diabetes or immune deficiency

name: Friedrich's Ataxia
description: Friedrich's ataxia is a rare inherited neurodegenerative disorder that causes progressive damage to the nervous system, affecting coordination and movement. It is caused by mutations in the FXN gene, leading to a lack of the protein frataxin.
treatment: No cure, but symptomatic treatments can improve quality of life
preventive_measures: Regular monitoring of neurological and cardiac function

name: Factor V Leiden Thrombophilia
description: Factor V Leiden thrombophilia is a genetic disorder that increases the risk of developing abnormal blood clots (thrombosis), particularly in veins. It results from a mutation in the Factor V gene, which affects blood clotting mechanisms.
treatment: Lifestyle changes to reduce clotting risks
preventive_measures: Genetic testing for those with a family history
Using blood thinners for high-risk individuals, particularly during pregnancy or surgery

name: Female Infertility
description: Female infertility refers to the inability of a woman to conceive after one year of regular, unprotected intercourse. It can be caused by various factors such as ovulatory disorders, blocked fallopian tubes, or endometriosis.
symptoms: Inability to conceive after a year of trying
treatment: Surgical treatments for underlying issues (e.g., blocked fallopian tubes)
Lifestyle modifications (e.g., maintaining a healthy weight)
preventive_measures: Early fertility assessments for women over 35
Avoiding smoking and excessive alcohol consumption

name: Frontotemporal Dementia
description: Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is a progressive neurodegenerative condition that primarily affects the frontal and temporal lobes of the brain. It leads to significant personality changes, behavioral issues, and cognitive decline.
symptoms: Motor symptoms like weakness or tremors
treatment: Medications to manage symptoms (e.g., antidepressants, antipsychotics)
Therapies for speech and behavior management
No cure, but treatments can help improve quality of life
preventive_measures: Early diagnosis and intervention to manage symptoms

name: Fanconi Anemia
description: Fanconi anemia is a rare inherited blood disorder that leads to bone marrow failure, increased risk of cancers, and developmental abnormalities. It is caused by mutations in genes responsible for DNA repair.
symptoms: Physical abnormalities such as short stature and skeletal abnormalities
Increased risk of leukemia and other cancers
preventive_measures: Early diagnosis and regular monitoring for complications

name: Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (Liver)
description: Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is a benign liver tumor that is generally asymptomatic and often discovered incidentally during imaging studies. It is the second most common benign liver lesion, typically seen in women.
symptoms: No other significant symptoms unless the tumor becomes large
treatment: Usually no treatment required for asymptomatic cases
Surgical removal or monitoring for large or symptomatic tumors
Regular follow-up with imaging to monitor growth
preventive_measures: No known specific preventive measures, but early detection through imaging can help avoid complications

name: Gastritis
description: Gastritis is the inflammation of the stomach lining, often caused by infections (particularly Helicobacter pylori), overuse of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), alcohol, or stress. It can lead to stomach pain, nausea, and vomiting.
treatment: Avoiding irritants such as alcohol or NSAIDs
preventive_measures: Follow a balanced diet low in irritants

name: Glaucoma
description: Glaucoma is a group of eye conditions that cause damage to the optic nerve, often due to increased intraocular pressure. It is a leading cause of blindness, and its progression can be slow, making early detection essential.
symptoms: Nausea and vomiting (in acute angle-closure glaucoma)
treatment: Medications (e.g., prostaglandin analogs, beta blockers) to lower intraocular pressure
preventive_measures: Early treatment of elevated intraocular pressure
Maintain a healthy lifestyle to reduce risk factors

name: Gout
description: Gout is a type of inflammatory arthritis caused by the accumulation of uric acid crystals in the joints. It typically affects the big toe but can impact other joints and is associated with a high-protein diet, obesity, and dehydration.
symptoms: Intense joint pain, especially in the big toe
Swelling and redness of affected joints
Limited range of motion in affected areas
preventive_measures: Limit alcohol and purine-rich foods (e.g., red meat, seafood)
Use medications to control uric acid levels

name: Gonorrhea
description: Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the bacterium *Neisseria gonorrhoeae*. It commonly affects the urethra, cervix, rectum, and throat, and can lead to serious complications if left untreated.
symptoms: Discharge from the penis or vagina
Sore throat (in cases of oral infection)
preventive_measures: Avoid sharing towels or clothing with infected individuals

name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
description: Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is a rare neurological disorder where the immune system mistakenly attacks the peripheral nerves, leading to weakness, numbness, and, in severe cases, paralysis. It is often preceded by an infection such as the flu or gastrointestinal illness.
symptoms: Muscle weakness or tingling that starts in the feet and legs
preventive_measures: Vaccination to prevent infections (e.g., influenza vaccine)

name: Gallstones
description: Gallstones are hardened deposits of bile in the gallbladder, often composed of cholesterol or bilirubin. They can vary in size and may block bile flow, causing pain and potential complications like pancreatitis.
symptoms: Severe pain in the upper right abdomen
Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
treatment: Shock wave lithotripsy for breaking up stones
preventive_measures: Maintain a healthy diet rich in fiber

name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
description: GERD is a chronic digestive condition where stomach acid or bile irritates the food pipe (esophagus). It leads to heartburn, regurgitation, and other symptoms.
treatment: Lifestyle changes (e.g., eating smaller meals, avoiding triggers like caffeine or alcohol)
preventive_measures: Avoid large meals and lying down right after eating
Elevate the head of the bed
Avoid trigger foods like spicy or fatty foods

name: Graves' Disease
description: Graves' disease is an autoimmune disorder that causes hyperthyroidism, where the thyroid gland produces excess thyroid hormones, leading to symptoms like increased metabolism and organ dysfunction.
preventive_measures: Early diagnosis and treatment of thyroid disorders

name: Gastric Cancer
description: Gastric cancer, or stomach cancer, begins in the lining of the stomach and can spread to other parts of the body. It is often diagnosed at an advanced stage because early symptoms are nonspecific.
preventive_measures: Avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption
Eat a healthy diet with plenty of fruits and vegetables

name: Gum Disease (Periodontal Disease)
description: Gum disease is an infection of the tissues that surround and support your teeth. It can range from gingivitis (mild inflammation) to periodontitis (severe gum infection).
preventive_measures: Eat a balanced diet to promote healthy gums

name: Germ Cell Tumor
description: Germ cell tumors are cancers that begin in the cells that form sperm or eggs. They can occur in the ovaries, testes, or other areas like the brain or chest.
symptoms: Pain or swelling in the affected area

name: Goiter
description: A goiter is an abnormal enlargement of the thyroid gland, which can occur due to iodine deficiency, autoimmune diseases, or thyroid dysfunction.
preventive_measures: Monitor thyroid health through regular check-ups

name: Glomerulonephritis
description: Glomerulonephritis is inflammation of the glomeruli (small filtering units) in the kidneys, which can result in kidney damage and reduced function. It can be caused by infections, autoimmune diseases, or other conditions.
symptoms: Swelling in the face, hands, and feet

name: Gastroenteritis
description: Gastroenteritis is an infection of the gastrointestinal tract, often caused by viruses, bacteria, or parasites. It results in inflammation and leads to symptoms like diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
treatment: Antibiotics or antivirals (if bacterial or viral infection is confirmed)

name: Genital Herpes
description: Genital herpes is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). It leads to painful sores or blisters on the genital and anal areas.
symptoms: Painful blisters or sores on the genital or anal area

name: G6PD Deficiency
description: G6PD deficiency is a genetic disorder where the body lacks an enzyme (glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase) necessary for protecting red blood cells from oxidative stress. This deficiency makes red blood cells prone to destruction under certain conditions, such as infections, taking specific medications, or consuming foods like fava beans. The condition can lead to hemolytic anemia, causing symptoms such as jaundice, fatigue, and dark-colored urine. Most individuals are asymptomatic unless exposed to triggers.
treatment: Avoidance of triggers (certain drugs, foods, infections)
preventive_measures: Avoid fava beans and specific medications

name: Gastrointestinal Bleeding
description: Gastrointestinal bleeding refers to any form of bleeding originating from the digestive tract. It can be caused by conditions like ulcers, diverticulosis, Crohn’s disease, or cancer. Symptoms can include vomiting blood, black stools, and abdominal pain. Bleeding can range from mild to severe and requires immediate attention, especially if it leads to shock or organ failure.
treatment: Proton pump inhibitors to reduce stomach acid
preventive_measures: Treat underlying conditions like ulcers or Crohn’s disease
Screening for colorectal cancer in high-risk individuals

name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
description: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is an autoimmune disease that causes inflammation of blood vessels (vasculitis), particularly affecting the respiratory tract and kidneys. This condition leads to the formation of granulomas (clusters of immune cells), which can damage organs. Symptoms include chronic sinusitis, lung issues, and kidney dysfunction. If untreated, GPA can be life-threatening, but it can be controlled with immunosuppressive therapy.
treatment: Dialysis or kidney transplant in severe kidney failure
preventive_measures: Regular follow-up with doctors to monitor organ function
Use of immunosuppressants with caution to avoid infections

name: Glycogen Storage Disease
description: Glycogen storage diseases (GSDs) are a group of inherited disorders caused by deficiencies in enzymes that help convert glycogen to glucose. This results in the buildup of glycogen in tissues and insufficient glucose supply for energy. Symptoms vary depending on the type of GSD but commonly include hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), muscle weakness, and growth problems. Treatment usually involves dietary management to avoid hypoglycemia.
treatment: Cornstarch to provide slow glucose release
Enzyme replacement therapy in some types
preventive_measures: Regular monitoring of liver and kidney function

name: Gluten Sensitivity
description: Gluten sensitivity, also known as non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS), is a condition in which individuals experience gastrointestinal discomfort and other symptoms after consuming gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. It is different from celiac disease, as it does not involve autoimmune damage to the small intestine. Symptoms may include bloating, diarrhea, fatigue, and headaches. Diagnosis is based on symptoms and the exclusion of other conditions.
preventive_measures: Strict adherence to a gluten-free diet
Avoidance of cross-contamination in food preparation

name: Granuloma Annulare
description: Granuloma annulare is a chronic skin condition that causes raised, red or purple lesions, typically arranged in rings or patches. It can appear anywhere on the body but is most commonly seen on the hands, feet, or legs. The exact cause of granuloma annulare is unknown, but it is believed to be linked to immune system dysfunction or underlying conditions such as diabetes.
symptoms: Lesions on hands, feet, or legs
treatment: Treatment of underlying conditions if identified
preventive_measures: Avoid skin trauma that can trigger lesions

name: Greenstick Fracture
description: A greenstick fracture is an incomplete fracture where the bone bends and cracks but does not break all the way through. It is more common in children whose bones are still flexible. Greenstick fractures usually occur due to falls or trauma. The injury is painful, and swelling around the fracture site is common. These fractures typically heal well with immobilization.
symptoms: Limited mobility of the affected limb
treatment: Casting or splinting to immobilize the bone
Physical therapy after the fracture heals
preventive_measures: Use safety gear for activities involving risk of falls
Encourage children to engage in safe play activities

name: Gouty Arthritis
description: Gouty arthritis, or gout, is a form of arthritis caused by the buildup of uric acid crystals in the joints. This typically occurs in the big toe but can affect other joints such as the knees, ankles, and elbows. Symptoms include severe pain, redness, and swelling, often following consumption of foods high in purines (e.g., red meat, seafood, alcohol). Acute gout attacks are usually sudden and may last for a few days. Long-term management focuses on reducing uric acid levels through medications and lifestyle changes.
symptoms: Tightness or difficulty moving the joint
treatment: NSAIDs or colchicine for acute attacks
Allopurinol or febuxostat to lower uric acid levels
Lifestyle changes like avoiding purine-rich foods and alcohol
Hydration to help flush out uric acid
preventive_measures: Avoid alcohol and foods rich in purines
Regular monitoring of uric acid levels
Stay hydrated to prevent uric acid buildup

name: Gestational Diabetes
description: Gestational diabetes is a form of diabetes that occurs during pregnancy when the body cannot produce enough insulin to meet the increased needs of pregnancy. This leads to elevated blood glucose levels, which can affect both the mother and baby. Gestational diabetes usually resolves after childbirth but increases the risk of developing type 2 diabetes later in life. Management involves controlling blood sugar levels through diet, exercise, and sometimes medication.
treatment: Dietary changes to control blood sugar
preventive_measures: Monitoring blood sugar levels in at-risk pregnancies

name: Giant Cell Arteritis
description: Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis, is an inflammatory condition that affects the blood vessels, especially the temporal arteries in the head. GCA is most common in older adults and can cause symptoms such as headache, vision problems, and scalp tenderness. If untreated, it can lead to blindness or stroke. Treatment typically involves corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and prevent complications.
treatment: Vision assessments to detect early complications
preventive_measures: Early detection and corticosteroid treatment to prevent vision loss

name: Gastric Ulcer
description: A gastric ulcer is a sore that forms on the lining of the stomach, often due to an imbalance between stomach acids and protective factors. Causes include infection with Helicobacter pylori bacteria, excessive use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), or stress. Symptoms include abdominal pain, bloating, nausea, and vomiting. Treatment includes medications to reduce stomach acid and antibiotics for bacterial infections.
treatment: Antibiotics to treat H. pylori infection
Antacids and H2 blockers to reduce stomach acid
Lifestyle changes such as avoiding NSAIDs and alcohol
preventive_measures: Avoid excessive alcohol consumption and smoking

name: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)
description: Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are a rare form of cancer that originates in the interstitial cells of Cajal in the digestive tract. They can occur anywhere along the GI tract, but most commonly in the stomach or small intestine. Symptoms may include abdominal pain, bleeding, or a lump in the abdomen. GISTs are usually treated with surgery and, in some cases, targeted therapy or chemotherapy.
treatment: Targeted therapy (e.g., imatinib) for unresectable tumors
preventive_measures: Early diagnosis through imaging and biopsy
Genetic counseling if familial cases are suspected

name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
description: Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) is a rare neurological disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the peripheral nerves, often triggered by an infection like the flu or Zika virus. Symptoms start with weakness or tingling in the legs and can progress to paralysis. While GBS can be life-threatening, most people recover with proper treatment, such as plasmapheresis or intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG).
symptoms: Weakness or tingling in the legs
Pain and numbness in the extremities
treatment: Physical therapy to restore muscle strength
preventive_measures: Vaccination to prevent infections that can trigger GBS
Prompt treatment of infections to minimize the risk of developing GBS

name: Hepatitis
description: Hepatitis is an inflammation of the liver that can be caused by viruses, alcohol consumption, autoimmune diseases, or medications. It can be acute or chronic and is classified into different types (A, B, C, D, and E), each with its own cause and severity. Hepatitis can lead to liver damage, cirrhosis, or liver cancer if left untreated. Symptoms often include jaundice, fatigue, nausea, and abdominal pain.
treatment: Lifestyle changes such as alcohol avoidance
Vaccines for hepatitis A and B
preventive_measures: Safe handling of food and water
Avoiding sharing needles or personal items

name: Hypertension
description: Hypertension, or high blood pressure, occurs when the force of blood against the walls of arteries is consistently too high. It can lead to serious health problems, including heart disease, stroke, and kidney damage. Often referred to as a 'silent killer', hypertension usually has no noticeable symptoms until significant damage occurs.
treatment: Lifestyle changes (dietary changes, exercise, weight management)

name: HIV/AIDS
description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) attacks the immune system, weakening the body’s ability to fight infections. If untreated, HIV can progress to Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS), a condition where the immune system is severely damaged. HIV is transmitted through bodily fluids and can be managed with antiretroviral therapy (ART), but there is currently no cure.
treatment: Regular monitoring of CD4 count and viral load
preventive_measures: Harm reduction for intravenous drug users

name: Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) Infection
description: Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) is a viral infection that causes sores, commonly around the mouth (HSV-1) or genitals (HSV-2). It is a lifelong infection with periodic outbreaks triggered by factors like stress, illness, or sun exposure. HSV is highly contagious and is spread through skin-to-skin contact.
symptoms: Itching or tingling around the affected area
treatment: Antiviral medications (e.g., acyclovir) to reduce outbreaks
preventive_measures: Avoid direct contact with sores during outbreaks
Use of antiviral medications to prevent transmission
Use of condoms during sexual activity

name: Heart Disease
description: Heart disease refers to a range of conditions affecting the heart, including coronary artery disease, heart attack, and arrhythmias. These conditions can result from poor lifestyle choices, genetics, and other factors like high blood pressure and high cholesterol. Heart disease is the leading cause of death globally.

name: Huntington's Disease
description: Huntington's disease is a genetic neurodegenerative disorder that causes progressive motor dysfunction, cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms. The condition is caused by mutations in the HTT gene and is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Symptoms typically appear in mid-adulthood and worsen over time.
treatment: Symptom management (e.g., medications for movement control and mood stabilization)

name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
description: Hodgkin's lymphoma is a type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system, specifically in the lymph nodes. It is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells in the affected tissue. Early symptoms include swollen lymph nodes, fever, weight loss, and night sweats. It is highly treatable, particularly if diagnosed early.
treatment: Stem cell transplant in severe cases
preventive_measures: Early detection through regular medical check-ups
Prompt treatment of infections to reduce risk of lymphatic system issues

name: Hypothyroidism
description: Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to a slowing of body processes. It can be caused by autoimmune diseases (e.g., Hashimoto's thyroiditis), iodine deficiency, or damage to the thyroid gland. Symptoms include fatigue, weight gain, and depression.
treatment: Dietary changes if iodine deficiency is present
preventive_measures: Dietary supplementation with iodine if needed

name: Hernia
description: A hernia occurs when an organ or fatty tissue pushes through a weak spot or tear in the surrounding muscle or connective tissue. Common types include inguinal, femoral, and hiatal hernias. Hernias may cause pain or discomfort, especially when lifting or straining.
symptoms: Pain or discomfort, particularly when lifting or bending
Heartburn or indigestion in the case of a hiatal hernia
treatment: Supportive devices such as hernia belts in some cases
preventive_measures: Good posture to avoid strain on abdominal muscles

name: Hemophilia
description: Hemophilia is a genetic bleeding disorder where blood doesn't clot properly due to insufficient clotting factors. The severity depends on the amount of clotting factor present in the blood. Individuals with hemophilia may experience spontaneous bleeding, or prolonged bleeding after injuries or surgeries.
symptoms: Joint pain or swelling due to internal bleeding
treatment: Avoidance of certain activities that increase the risk of injury

name: Hives (Urticaria)
description: Hives, or urticaria, are raised, itchy welts on the skin that occur due to an allergic reaction, stress, or other triggers. These welts can appear suddenly and vary in size. The condition can be acute (lasting less than six weeks) or chronic (lasting longer).
symptoms: Swelling of the lips, eyes, or throat in severe cases
preventive_measures: Use of prescribed antihistamines during flare-ups

name: Hyperthyroidism
description: Hyperthyroidism is a condition where the thyroid gland produces too much thyroid hormone, speeding up the body's processes. Common causes include Graves' disease, toxic nodular goiter, and thyroiditis. Symptoms include weight loss, rapid heartbeat, and anxiety.
symptoms: Weight loss despite normal or increased appetite
treatment: Surgery to remove part of the thyroid

name: Heart Attack (Myocardial Infarction)
description: A heart attack occurs when the blood flow to part of the heart muscle is blocked, typically by a blood clot. This leads to damage or death of the heart tissue. Risk factors include coronary artery disease, high blood pressure, smoking, and diabetes.
preventive_measures: Control of blood pressure and cholesterol

name: Hepatic Encephalopathy
description: Hepatic encephalopathy is a decline in brain function as a result of severe liver disease. It is commonly caused by cirrhosis or hepatitis, leading to a build-up of toxins in the blood that affect the brain.

name: Hepatocellular Carcinoma
description: Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common type of liver cancer, typically arising in individuals with chronic liver disease, such as cirrhosis or hepatitis. It can present with vague symptoms but can often be diagnosed through imaging studies and biopsy.
preventive_measures: Regular monitoring in at-risk populations (e.g., cirrhosis patients)

name: Hallucinations
description: Hallucinations are sensory experiences that occur without an external stimulus. They can affect any of the five senses, including sight, sound, smell, taste, or touch. Hallucinations are typically associated with mental health conditions like schizophrenia, but can also occur in neurological disorders (e.g., Parkinson's disease), as well as from substance use, withdrawal, or sleep deprivation.
symptoms: Seeing or hearing things that are not present
Inability to distinguish between reality and illusion
treatment: Treatment of underlying conditions (e.g., neurological disorders or substance abuse)

name: Hemorrhoids
description: Hemorrhoids are swollen veins in the lower rectum or anus that can cause pain, itching, and bleeding. They are often caused by prolonged straining during bowel movements, pregnancy, obesity, or a sedentary lifestyle. Hemorrhoids may be internal or external, with external hemorrhoids being more painful.
symptoms: Pain or discomfort during bowel movements
Itching or swelling around the anus
Bright red blood on toilet paper or in the stool
preventive_measures: Avoiding prolonged sitting on the toilet

name: Hypoglycemia
description: Hypoglycemia is a condition where blood glucose (sugar) levels fall below normal, which can lead to symptoms such as shaking, confusion, and in severe cases, loss of consciousness. It is commonly seen in people with diabetes who are on insulin or other medications that lower blood sugar, but it can also occur due to prolonged fasting or excessive alcohol consumption.
treatment: Consuming fast-acting carbohydrates (e.g., glucose tablets, fruit juice)

name: Hyperlipidemia
description: Hyperlipidemia is a condition characterized by high levels of lipids (fats) in the blood, particularly cholesterol and triglycerides. This can increase the risk of heart disease, stroke, and other cardiovascular problems. It is often related to poor dietary habits, obesity, lack of exercise, or genetic factors.
symptoms: Signs of cardiovascular disease in severe cases (e.g., chest pain, shortness of breath)
treatment: Lifestyle changes (dietary modifications, weight loss, exercise)
Control of underlying conditions like diabetes or hypertension
preventive_measures: Healthy diet low in saturated fats

name: Herpes Zoster (Shingles)
description: Herpes Zoster, commonly known as shingles, is a reactivation of the chickenpox virus (varicella-zoster) that typically occurs years after an initial infection. It causes a painful rash, usually on one side of the body or face, and can lead to long-term nerve pain called postherpetic neuralgia.
symptoms: Painful rash, usually on one side of the body
treatment: Vaccination to prevent shingles in older adults
preventive_measures: Early antiviral treatment to reduce severity

name: Hysteria
description: Hysteria, often considered a historical diagnosis, refers to a state of excessive emotional reactions or psychological distress, sometimes resulting in physical symptoms. It is now generally recognized as a part of the spectrum of conversion disorder or somatic symptom disorder in modern psychiatry. It can involve extreme anxiety, irrational behaviors, and physical manifestations like paralysis or blindness.
symptoms: Physical symptoms with no medical cause
treatment: Medication for underlying anxiety or depression

name: Hydrocephalus
description: Hydrocephalus is a condition where there is an abnormal accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the ventricles of the brain, leading to increased pressure inside the skull. This can cause damage to brain tissues and interfere with brain function. It can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired later in life.
treatment: Surgical insertion of a shunt to drain excess fluid
preventive_measures: Prenatal care to reduce risks of congenital hydrocephalus
Early diagnosis and treatment to prevent brain damage

name: Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease
description: Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) is a viral illness common in young children, caused by the coxsackievirus. It is characterized by fever, sores in the mouth, and a rash on the hands and feet. While it is generally mild, it can lead to complications like dehydration or viral meningitis in rare cases.
symptoms: Rash on hands, feet, and sometimes buttocks
preventive_measures: Avoiding close contact with infected individuals

name: Histoplasmosis
description: Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection caused by the Histoplasma capsulatum fungus, typically found in soil contaminated by bird or bat droppings. People can inhale the spores when exposed to contaminated environments. Symptoms can range from mild to severe, and the disease primarily affects the lungs.
preventive_measures: Wearing protective equipment when working in high-risk areas

name: Hypercalcemia
description: Hypercalcemia is a condition characterized by elevated levels of calcium in the blood. It can result from various causes, including overactive parathyroid glands, certain cancers, or excessive use of calcium or vitamin D supplements. High calcium levels can lead to kidney stones, bone pain, and neurological symptoms.
treatment: Treatment of underlying causes (e.g., parathyroid surgery)
preventive_measures: Monitoring calcium levels in high-risk individuals

name: Hemorrhagic Stroke
description: Hemorrhagic stroke occurs when a blood vessel in the brain ruptures, causing bleeding in the brain tissue. This leads to increased pressure in the brain and can result in significant damage to brain cells. It is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention.
symptoms: Weakness or numbness on one side of the body
treatment: Surgical intervention to repair the blood vessel
Rehabilitation to regain function after stroke
preventive_measures: Avoiding smoking and excessive alcohol use
Management of underlying conditions like diabetes or high cholesterol

name: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Infection
description: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is a group of viruses that can infect the genital area, throat, or other parts of the body. It is the most common sexually transmitted infection and can cause genital warts or lead to certain types of cancers, including cervical cancer.
symptoms: Throat warts or changes in the voice (in rare cases)
treatment: Vaccination to prevent high-risk types of HPV
preventive_measures: Regular screening for cervical cancer in women

name: Haploinsufficiency
description: Haploinsufficiency occurs when a person has only one functional copy of a gene instead of the normal two, leading to insufficient production of a protein necessary for proper cellular function. This can result in various genetic disorders, including some forms of cancer or developmental delays.
symptoms: Genetic disorders related to insufficient protein production
preventive_measures: Genetic testing and counseling for at-risk families

name: Hydronephrosis
description: Hydronephrosis is the swelling of one or both kidneys due to a build-up of urine caused by an obstruction or blockage in the urinary tract. It can result from kidney stones, enlarged prostate, or congenital abnormalities.
symptoms: Pain in the side or lower back
treatment: Surgical intervention to relieve the blockage
Treatment of underlying causes (e.g., kidney stone removal, prostate treatment)
preventive_measures: Early detection and treatment of urinary tract obstructions
Management of risk factors like kidney stones or BPH

name: Influenza
description: Influenza, commonly known as the flu, is a highly contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses. It can cause mild to severe illness, with symptoms such as fever, cough, body aches, and fatigue. The flu can lead to complications like pneumonia, especially in vulnerable populations such as the elderly or immunocompromised individuals.
treatment: Antiviral medications (e.g., oseltamivir) for severe cases
preventive_measures: Avoiding close contact with infected individuals

name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
description: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) is a common gastrointestinal disorder characterized by abdominal pain, bloating, and changes in bowel habits, such as diarrhea or constipation. The exact cause is unknown, but it may be related to abnormal muscle contractions in the intestines or an imbalance in gut bacteria. Stress and diet can exacerbate symptoms.
treatment: Medications to manage symptoms (antispasmodics, laxatives, anti-diarrheal agents)

name: Infections (Various Causes)
description: Infections are caused by harmful microorganisms, such as bacteria, viruses, fungi, or parasites. Symptoms depend on the type of infection, its location, and its severity. Infections can range from mild conditions like the common cold to life-threatening ones like sepsis.
symptoms: Pain or inflammation at the site of infection
treatment: Antibiotics, antivirals, antifungals, or antiparasitic medications depending on the cause
Supportive care such as pain relief or fever management
preventive_measures: Avoiding close contact with infected individuals

name: Immunodeficiency Disorders
description: Immunodeficiency disorders are conditions where the immune system is weakened or absent, making the body more susceptible to infections. These disorders can be inherited (e.g., primary immunodeficiency) or acquired (e.g., HIV/AIDS).

name: Irritable Larynx Syndrome
description: Irritable Larynx Syndrome (ILS) is a condition that affects the vocal cords, causing them to become hypersensitive and overreact to irritants. It often presents with symptoms like a sore throat, hoarseness, and a dry cough. Triggers can include smoke, air pollution, postnasal drip, and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

name: Insomnia
description: Insomnia is a sleep disorder characterized by difficulty falling asleep, staying asleep, or waking up too early and not being able to go back to sleep. It can be caused by stress, anxiety, depression, poor sleep hygiene, or underlying medical conditions.
symptoms: Waking up frequently during the night
treatment: Medications like sleep aids or sedatives
preventive_measures: Avoiding caffeine and electronics before bed

name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
description: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory conditions of the gastrointestinal tract, including Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. These diseases cause symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss, and can lead to severe complications like intestinal obstruction or perforation.
preventive_measures: Avoiding triggers (e.g., certain foods or stress)
Regular monitoring by a healthcare provider

name: Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis
description: Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a chronic, progressive lung disease characterized by scarring (fibrosis) of the lung tissue. The cause is unknown, but it can lead to difficulty breathing, coughing, and a decreased ability to engage in physical activity.
symptoms: Clubbing of fingers or toes (in severe cases)

name: Impetigo
description: Impetigo is a highly contagious bacterial skin infection that commonly affects children. It is caused by either Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. Impetigo typically appears as red sores that rupture and form honey-colored crusts.
symptoms: Red sores that form honey-colored crusts
treatment: Good hygiene and cleaning of infected areas
preventive_measures: Avoiding direct contact with infected individuals

name: Ischemic Heart Disease
description: Ischemic heart disease (IHD), also known as coronary artery disease, occurs when there is reduced blood flow to the heart due to blockages in the coronary arteries. This can lead to chest pain (angina) or heart attacks. It is typically caused by atherosclerosis, where fatty deposits build up in the arteries.
preventive_measures: Managing risk factors like high blood pressure, cholesterol, and diabetes

name: Intermittent Claudication
description: Intermittent claudication is a condition characterized by pain and cramping in the legs that occurs with physical activity and is relieved by rest. It is caused by reduced blood flow to the muscles, often due to peripheral artery disease (PAD).
symptoms: Pain or cramping in the legs during exercise
Weak or absent pulses in the legs
treatment: Surgical intervention in severe cases (e.g., angioplasty)
preventive_measures: Management of underlying conditions (e.g., diabetes, hypertension, high cholesterol)

name: Insulin Resistance
description: Insulin resistance occurs when the body's cells become less responsive to insulin, leading to higher blood glucose levels. This condition is a precursor to type 2 diabetes and is often associated with obesity, physical inactivity, and poor diet.

name: Intestinal Obstruction
description: Intestinal obstruction occurs when the normal flow of contents through the intestines is blocked. This can be caused by physical blockages, such as adhesions, tumors, or hernias, or by impaired muscle function in the intestines. It can lead to severe pain, vomiting, and bowel dysfunction.
symptoms: Constipation or inability to pass gas
preventive_measures: Management of risk factors like hernias or abdominal surgeries

name: Intestinal Worms
description: Intestinal worms, or helminth infections, are caused by parasitic worms that infect the intestines. Common types include roundworms, tapeworms, and hookworms. These infections are often transmitted through contaminated food, water, or soil.
preventive_measures: Avoiding consumption of contaminated food or water

name: Infective Endocarditis
description: Infective endocarditis is a life-threatening infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers and valves, usually caused by bacteria. The infection can lead to serious complications like heart failure, stroke, or systemic emboli. Common risk factors include heart valve disease, implanted heart devices, and intravenous drug use.
symptoms: Swelling in the legs or abdomen
treatment: Surgical intervention for valve repair or replacement in severe cases
preventive_measures: Antibiotic prophylaxis before certain medical procedures

name: Invasive Candidiasis
description: Invasive candidiasis is a serious fungal infection caused by *Candida* species, commonly *Candida albicans*. It occurs when the fungus spreads from mucosal surfaces into the bloodstream or internal organs, affecting the heart, kidneys, brain, and eyes. It is most common in immunocompromised patients, including those with cancer, diabetes, or those on broad-spectrum antibiotics.
preventive_measures: Early detection and treatment of infections

name: Induced Abortion
description: Induced abortion, also known as therapeutic abortion, is the medical or surgical termination of a pregnancy before the fetus can live independently outside the womb. This procedure is carried out for various reasons, including maternal health risks, fetal abnormalities, or personal choice.
treatment: Medical abortion (using medications like mifepristone and misoprostol)
Surgical procedures (e.g., aspiration or dilation and curettage)
preventive_measures: Access to family planning and contraceptive services

name: Incontinentia Pigmenti
description: Incontinentia pigmenti is a rare genetic condition that affects the skin, teeth, hair, and central nervous system. It is typically caused by mutations in the *IKBKG* gene and is usually inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern. The condition is characterized by skin rashes, changes in skin pigmentation, and dental abnormalities.
treatment: Management of complications like retinal and neurological issues
preventive_measures: Genetic counseling for families with a history of the condition

name: Increased Intracranial Pressure
description: Increased intracranial pressure (ICP) occurs when the pressure inside the skull rises, usually due to swelling of the brain, bleeding, or other factors. ICP can lead to serious consequences, such as brain damage, coma, or death, if not managed promptly.
treatment: Intubation and ventilation in severe cases
preventive_measures: Early detection and management of head trauma or neurological conditions
Prompt treatment of brain infections or hemorrhage

name: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
description: Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is a condition where the immune system mistakenly destroys platelets, leading to an increased risk of bleeding. The cause is often unknown, but it can sometimes follow a viral infection. Symptoms include easy bruising, petechiae, and heavy menstrual bleeding.
symptoms: Petechiae (small red or purple spots on the skin)
preventive_measures: Avoiding activities that increase the risk of bleeding

name: Infertility
description: Infertility is the inability to conceive after one year of regular, unprotected sex. It can be caused by various factors in both men and women, including hormonal imbalances, ovulation disorders, low sperm count, or structural issues in the reproductive organs.
symptoms: Irregular or absent menstrual periods in women
Low sperm count or abnormal sperm morphology in men
preventive_measures: Regular medical check-ups for reproductive health

name: Invasive Pneumococcal Disease
description: Invasive pneumococcal disease is caused by the bacterium *Streptococcus pneumoniae* and includes severe infections such as pneumonia, meningitis, and bacteremia. It is particularly dangerous in young children, the elderly, and those with weakened immune systems.

name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
description: Iron deficiency anemia is a common type of anemia caused by insufficient iron in the body. Iron is essential for producing hemoglobin, which helps red blood cells carry oxygen. This condition can lead to fatigue, weakness, and other symptoms of low oxygen supply.
treatment: Iron-rich diet (e.g., red meat, spinach, legumes)
Treatment of underlying conditions causing the deficiency
preventive_measures: Monitoring of iron levels in high-risk groups (e.g., pregnant women, young children)

name: Ichthyosis
description: Ichthyosis is a group of genetic skin disorders characterized by dry, scaly skin. The severity can vary, with some forms presenting mild symptoms and others causing significant discomfort and thickening of the skin. The condition can affect both the appearance and function of the skin.
symptoms: Cracks or splits in the skin
treatment: Management of complications like skin infections
preventive_measures: Genetic counseling for families with a history of the condition

name: Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura
description: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is a disorder in which the immune system destroys platelets, leading to an increased risk of bleeding. It can occur suddenly or chronically and is often diagnosed by a low platelet count in the blood. The exact cause is unknown, but it can be triggered by infections or other immune system issues.
treatment: Splenectomy in severe or chronic cases
preventive_measures: Avoiding activities that could lead to injury or bleeding

name: Inguinal Hernia
description: An inguinal hernia occurs when part of the intestine bulges through a weak spot in the abdominal muscles, usually in the groin area. It is more common in men and may result from lifting heavy objects, straining during bowel movements, or congenital weakness.
symptoms: Pain or discomfort at the site
Pain that worsens with coughing or lifting
treatment: Lifestyle changes to avoid strain on the abdomen

name: Inflammatory Arthritis
description: Inflammatory arthritis is a group of disorders that cause inflammation of the joints, leading to pain, swelling, and stiffness. Common types include rheumatoid arthritis and psoriatic arthritis. These conditions can cause long-term damage to the joints if left untreated.

name: Infection Control Issues
description: Infection control issues arise in healthcare settings or communities when infections spread due to inadequate practices in hygiene, sterilization, or disease prevention. These issues can lead to outbreaks of infectious diseases, particularly in hospitals or long-term care facilities.

name: Intradermal Nevi
description: Intradermal nevi are benign skin lesions or moles that develop in the dermal layer of the skin. They are typically flesh-colored, raised, and have a smooth surface. While most intradermal nevi are harmless, they may be removed if they cause cosmetic concerns or have features that resemble skin cancer.
treatment: Removal for cosmetic or medical reasons (e.g., biopsy to rule out malignancy)
preventive_measures: Sun protection to prevent skin damage

name: Jaundice
description: Jaundice is a condition where the skin, sclerae (white part of the eyes), and mucous membranes turn yellow due to the accumulation of bilirubin, a yellow pigment produced by the breakdown of red blood cells. It is often a symptom of an underlying problem with the liver, gallbladder, or red blood cells.
symptoms: Yellowing of the skin and eyes
treatment: Treating the underlying cause (e.g., liver disease, bile duct obstruction)
preventive_measures: Regular monitoring of liver function in at-risk individuals
Vaccination for hepatitis to prevent liver disease

name: Jacuzzi Burns
description: Jacuzzi burns are a type of burn injury caused by prolonged exposure to hot water in Jacuzzis or hot tubs. The burns occur when the skin is exposed to water temperatures that are too high, leading to first, second, or third-degree burns.
symptoms: Redness or blistering of the skin
Peeling of the skin in severe cases
treatment: Cooling the affected area with lukewarm water
Seeking medical attention for severe burns
preventive_measures: Ensuring proper water temperature in Jacuzzis
Limiting exposure time to hot water

name: Jock Itch (Tinea Cruris)
description: Jock itch, or tinea cruris, is a fungal infection that affects the groin area, causing itching, redness, and a ring-shaped rash. It is caused by dermatophytes, a type of fungi that thrive in warm, moist environments.
treatment: Keeping the affected area dry and clean
preventive_measures: Maintaining good hygiene in the groin area
Using antifungal powders in hot, humid conditions

name: Jellyfish Stings
description: Jellyfish stings occur when a person comes into contact with the tentacles of a jellyfish, leading to a painful reaction caused by the release of venom from specialized cells called nematocysts. Some jellyfish species can cause severe reactions, including anaphylaxis.
symptoms: Redness or welts on the skin
treatment: Seeking emergency medical attention for severe reactions
preventive_measures: Wearing protective clothing or nets while swimming

name: Juvenile Diabetes
description: Juvenile diabetes, also known as Type 1 diabetes, is a chronic condition in which the pancreas produces little or no insulin, a hormone necessary for the body to convert food into energy. It is typically diagnosed in children and young adults and requires lifelong insulin therapy.
preventive_measures: Early detection and treatment to manage blood sugar levels

name: Juvenile Arthritis
description: Juvenile arthritis is an autoimmune condition that causes inflammation in the joints of children. The exact cause is unknown, but it involves the immune system mistakenly attacking healthy tissues. Symptoms include joint pain, swelling, and stiffness.
preventive_measures: Early diagnosis and treatment to prevent joint damage

name: Jungle Fever (Malaria)
description: Jungle fever, commonly known as malaria, is a life-threatening disease caused by *Plasmodium* parasites, which are transmitted to humans through the bites of infected Anopheles mosquitoes. It is prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions.
preventive_measures: Taking prophylactic antimalarial drugs when traveling to endemic areas

name: Jervell and Lange-Nielsen Syndrome
description: Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by congenital deafness and long QT syndrome, which can cause heart arrhythmias and increase the risk of sudden cardiac death.
symptoms: Fainting or seizures due to arrhythmias
treatment: Use of hearing aids or cochlear implants
preventive_measures: Genetic counseling for families with a history of the syndrome
Early cardiac intervention to manage arrhythmias

name: Jordan's Syndrome
description: Jordan's syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that involves hearing loss, developmental delays, and other neurological symptoms. It is caused by mutations in the *SLC26A4* gene and is characterized by progressive loss of hearing and balance.
preventive_measures: Genetic counseling for families with a history of the condition

name: Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy
description: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) is a type of epilepsy that usually starts in adolescence. It is characterized by myoclonic seizures (sudden, brief jerks or twitches), generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and absence seizures.
preventive_measures: Early diagnosis and adherence to medication regimens to prevent seizures

name: Johne's Disease
description: Johne's disease is a chronic, infectious disease that primarily affects the intestines of ruminants, such as cows and sheep, and can cause severe diarrhea, weight loss, and reduced milk production. It is caused by the bacterium *Mycobacterium avium* subspecies *paratuberculosis*.
treatment: There is no cure; management involves controlling symptoms and preventing transmission
preventive_measures: Good hygiene and management practices in livestock
Preventing contamination of food and water supplies

name: Japanese Encephalitis
description: Japanese encephalitis is a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes, causing inflammation of the brain. It is most common in East Asia and the Pacific Islands. The virus can lead to severe neurological complications, including encephalitis, seizures, and even death.
preventive_measures: Avoiding mosquito bites in endemic areas

name: Junctional Tachycardia
description: Junctional tachycardia is a type of arrhythmia where the heart rate is abnormally fast, originating in the atrioventricular junction (where the atria and ventricles meet). This condition can cause palpitations, dizziness, or fainting.
preventive_measures: Monitoring heart health in at-risk individuals
Avoiding stimulants such as caffeine or alcohol

name: Joint Dislocation
description: A joint dislocation occurs when the bones that form a joint are forced out of their normal position. This injury typically results from trauma or excessive force on the joint, leading to pain, swelling, and impaired function.
treatment: Physical therapy to regain strength and range of motion
preventive_measures: Strengthening muscles around joints to prevent injury

name: Joint Pain (Arthralgia)
description: Arthralgia refers to joint pain without inflammation. It can be caused by a variety of factors, including injury, overuse, infections, or underlying medical conditions such as arthritis.
symptoms: Pain in one or more joints
preventive_measures: Maintaining a healthy weight to reduce joint strain

name: Jaundice (Neonatal)
description: Neonatal jaundice is common in newborns, where the skin and eyes appear yellow due to elevated bilirubin levels. It often occurs because a newborn's liver is immature and unable to process bilirubin efficiently. While typically harmless, severe jaundice can lead to brain damage if untreated.
symptoms: Yellowing of the skin and eyes
treatment: Frequent feeding to promote bilirubin excretion
preventive_measures: Early treatment if jaundice is detected

name: Jumping Frenchmen of Maine
description: Jumping Frenchmen of Maine is a rare neurological disorder characterized by exaggerated startle reactions to stimuli. Individuals with this condition may respond to unexpected stimuli with movements like jumping, shouting, or other involuntary motions. It was first observed in the French-Canadian population in Maine and is believed to be genetically inherited.
treatment: There is no specific cure, but medications such as tranquilizers or antidepressants may help control symptoms
Behavioral therapy may assist with managing reactions
preventive_measures: Genetic counseling for families with a history of the condition

name: Jaundice (Obstructive)
description: Obstructive jaundice occurs when a blockage in the bile ducts prevents bile from being excreted properly. This leads to a buildup of bilirubin in the bloodstream, causing yellowing of the skin and eyes. The blockage can be caused by conditions like gallstones, tumors, or strictures in the bile ducts.
symptoms: Yellowing of the skin and eyes
Abdominal pain or discomfort (especially in the upper right abdomen)
treatment: Treating underlying causes like gallstones or tumors
preventive_measures: Prompt treatment of gallstones or other bile duct issues

name: Junctional Ectopic Tachycardia
description: Junctional ectopic tachycardia (JET) is a rare heart rhythm disorder where the heart beats abnormally fast due to electrical impulses originating from areas near the atrioventricular (AV) node, outside the normal pacemaker region of the heart. This condition can cause rapid, abnormal heartbeats and is often seen in newborns or children.
treatment: Medications like beta-blockers or antiarrhythmic drugs
In severe cases, electrical cardioversion or catheter ablation may be needed
preventive_measures: Monitoring heart rhythm in individuals at risk, such as those with congenital heart defects

name: Joubert Syndrome
description: Joubert syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects the brain's cerebellum, leading to developmental delays, motor coordination problems, and intellectual disabilities. It can also cause abnormal eye movements, breathing problems, and other neurological symptoms.
treatment: There is no cure, but early intervention with physical, occupational, and speech therapy can help manage symptoms
Supportive care to address breathing or motor coordination problems
preventive_measures: Genetic counseling for families with a history of Joubert syndrome

name: Jumper's Knee (Patellar Tendonitis)
description: Jumper's knee, or patellar tendonitis, is an overuse injury that affects the patellar tendon, which connects the kneecap (patella) to the shinbone. It is commonly seen in athletes, especially those who participate in jumping sports like basketball and volleyball.
symptoms: Swelling or tenderness around the patellar tendon
Pain aggravated by activities such as jumping or squatting
treatment: Rest and ice to reduce inflammation
Physical therapy to strengthen muscles around the knee
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain relief
In some cases, corticosteroid injections or surgery may be needed
preventive_measures: Proper warm-up and stretching before physical activity
Strengthening exercises for the quadriceps and hamstrings

name: Jelly Belly (Bloating)
description: Jelly belly, or bloating, refers to a feeling of fullness or distention in the abdomen due to excess gas, fluid, or food. It is a common condition that can occur after eating, especially with foods that are difficult to digest.
symptoms: Feeling of fullness or tightness in the abdomen
Discomfort or mild pain in the abdomen
treatment: Dietary changes to avoid gas-producing foods
Over-the-counter medications such as simethicone to relieve gas
preventive_measures: Avoiding foods that are high in fiber, carbonated beverages, or artificial sweeteners

name: JRA (Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis)
description: Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (JRA) is a chronic autoimmune disease that causes inflammation in the joints of children. It can lead to pain, stiffness, and swelling, and in severe cases, joint damage. The cause is unknown but is believed to involve genetic and environmental factors.
treatment: In severe cases, biologic therapies or corticosteroids
preventive_measures: Early diagnosis and treatment to prevent joint damage

name: Junctional Bradycardia
description: Junctional bradycardia is a heart condition where the heart rate is slower than normal due to electrical impulses originating from the junctional area near the AV node, rather than from the heart's natural pacemaker, the sinoatrial (SA) node.
symptoms: Slow heart rate (usually below 60 beats per minute)
treatment: In some cases, no treatment is needed if symptoms are mild
If symptomatic, treatment may involve medications like atropine or pacemaker implantation
preventive_measures: Regular heart health monitoring for individuals with risk factors

name: Jod-Basedow Syndrome
description: Jod-Basedow syndrome is a form of hyperthyroidism that can occur in individuals with pre-existing thyroid disease when they are exposed to excess iodine, often from iodine-containing medications or radiographic contrast agents. It leads to an overactive thyroid gland and symptoms of hyperthyroidism.
treatment: In some cases, thyroid surgery or radioactive iodine treatment may be necessary
preventive_measures: Avoiding excessive iodine intake, especially in individuals with pre-existing thyroid conditions

name: Jaundice (Hemolytic)
description: Hemolytic jaundice occurs when red blood cells are destroyed faster than they can be replaced, leading to an excess of bilirubin in the bloodstream. This type of jaundice is often caused by conditions such as hemolytic anemia, infections, or autoimmune diseases.
symptoms: Yellowing of the skin and eyes
Enlarged spleen or liver (in some cases)
treatment: Treating the underlying cause (e.g., managing hemolytic anemia)
In some cases, medications like corticosteroids may be used
preventive_measures: Managing conditions that can lead to hemolysis, such as infections or autoimmune diseases

name: Jarisch-Herxheimer Reaction
description: The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is a temporary worsening of symptoms that can occur after starting antibiotic treatment for certain bacterial infections, such as syphilis or Lyme disease. It is believed to be caused by the release of endotoxins from the dying bacteria.
symptoms: Worsening of the skin rash or symptoms related to the infection
treatment: Supportive care with fluids and antipyretics
Monitoring symptoms to ensure they resolve as treatment continues
preventive_measures: There is no known prevention, but the reaction is typically self-limited and resolves within 24-48 hours

name: Junctional Rhythm
description: Junctional rhythm is a type of abnormal heart rhythm where electrical impulses originate from the AV node or the junction between the atria and ventricles, rather than from the sinoatrial node, the heart's normal pacemaker. This rhythm can be slower than normal and may cause symptoms.
treatment: In some cases, no treatment is needed
Medications such as atropine to increase heart rate if symptoms are severe
preventive_measures: Monitoring for heart rhythm abnormalities in individuals with risk factors

name: Juvenile Huntington's Disease
description: Juvenile Huntington's disease is a rare, genetic disorder that causes progressive neurodegeneration in children. It leads to a combination of movement problems, cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms, often appearing before the age of 20.
symptoms: Psychiatric symptoms such as depression or irritability
treatment: There is no cure, but medications may help manage symptoms
Therapies to support motor function and cognitive skills
preventive_measures: Genetic counseling for families with a history of Huntington's disease

name: Kawasaki Disease
description: Kawasaki disease is a rare, childhood inflammatory condition that affects the blood vessels, particularly the coronary arteries. It causes fever, rash, swelling of the hands and feet, and can lead to heart complications if left untreated. The exact cause is unknown, but it may be triggered by an infection or immune system response.
symptoms: Fever lasting more than five days
Redness and swelling of hands and feet
treatment: Close monitoring for heart complications like coronary artery aneurysms
preventive_measures: Early diagnosis and treatment with IVIG to reduce heart complications

name: Knee Osteoarthritis
description: Knee osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage in the knee. It leads to pain, swelling, and limited movement, affecting the quality of life, especially in older adults.
symptoms: Swelling or stiffness in the knee
A feeling of instability or buckling in the knee
treatment: Pain relievers like acetaminophen or NSAIDs
Physical therapy to strengthen muscles around the knee
In severe cases, knee replacement surgery
preventive_measures: Maintaining a healthy weight to reduce stress on the knee
Regular exercise to keep the knee joint flexible

name: Klinefelter Syndrome
description: Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic condition where males have an extra X chromosome. It affects physical and cognitive development and may result in infertility, low testosterone, and learning disabilities.
treatment: Testosterone replacement therapy to manage symptoms
Speech and physical therapy for developmental delays
preventive_measures: Early diagnosis and hormonal therapy for better outcomes

name: Keratitis
description: Keratitis is an inflammation of the cornea, usually caused by infections, injury, or wearing contact lenses for too long. It can lead to vision problems if not treated promptly.
symptoms: Feeling of something in the eye
treatment: Steroid eye drops to reduce inflammation
Proper hygiene and avoiding contact lens wear

name: Kidney Stones
description: Kidney stones are hard deposits of minerals and salts that form inside the kidneys. They can cause severe pain, usually when they move into the ureter. The pain can be intense and may require medical treatment to remove or pass the stones.
symptoms: Severe pain in the back or side
treatment: Drinking fluids to help pass small stones
Shock wave lithotripsy to break up stones
preventive_measures: Avoiding foods high in oxalate and sodium
Taking medications to prevent stone formation

name: Klebsiella Infection
description: Klebsiella infection is a bacterial infection caused by Klebsiella species, commonly found in the gut and environment. It can cause a variety of infections, including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and sepsis.

name: Knee Ligament Injuries
description: Knee ligament injuries typically involve the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL), posterior cruciate ligament (PCL), medial collateral ligament (MCL), or lateral collateral ligament (LCL). These injuries often occur due to sports activities or accidents.
symptoms: Instability or giving way of the knee
preventive_measures: Warm-up and stretching before physical activity

name: Kaposi's Sarcoma
description: Kaposi's sarcoma is a cancer that causes red, purple, or brown skin lesions. It primarily affects people with weakened immune systems, such as those with HIV/AIDS, and can affect internal organs.
symptoms: Lesions on the skin or mucous membranes
Pain or swelling in affected areas
Shortness of breath if the lungs are involved
preventive_measures: Regular medical checkups for early detection

name: Kuru
description: Kuru is a rare, degenerative neurological disorder caused by prions. It was historically seen in the Fore people of Papua New Guinea due to the practice of ritualistic cannibalism.
treatment: There is no cure for Kuru

name: Keratoconus
description: Keratoconus is a condition where the cornea thins and bulges into a cone shape, leading to vision problems such as blurred vision, glare, and sensitivity to light.
treatment: Eyeglasses or contact lenses for mild cases
Corneal crosslinking to strengthen the cornea
preventive_measures: Early treatment for those at risk

name: Krabbe Disease
description: Krabbe disease is a rare, inherited disorder that affects the nervous system, causing the breakdown of nerve cells due to the deficiency of an enzyme. It leads to severe neurological symptoms and is often fatal in early childhood.
treatment: Stem cell or bone marrow transplant
preventive_measures: Genetic counseling for families with a history of Krabbe disease

name: Kallmann Syndrome
description: Kallmann syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by a failure to start or fully complete puberty, often due to a lack of certain hormones. It is associated with anosmia (loss of sense of smell).
symptoms: Abnormal development of secondary sexual characteristics
treatment: Hormone replacement therapy to induce puberty
preventive_measures: Genetic counseling for families with a history of Kallmann syndrome

name: Keloids
description: Keloids are raised, thickened scars that form at the site of an injury or incision. They occur due to an overproduction of collagen during the healing process. Keloids may be larger than the original wound and can cause discomfort or aesthetic concerns.
symptoms: Raised, red, or darkened scar tissue
Itching or pain around the scar
Increased size of the scar over time
treatment: Laser treatment to flatten the keloid
preventive_measures: Avoiding injury to areas prone to keloids
Use of pressure garments or silicone sheets to prevent growth

name: Kawasaki Syndrome
description: Kawasaki syndrome, also known as Kawasaki disease, is a childhood illness that involves inflammation of the blood vessels. It can lead to serious complications, especially affecting the coronary arteries, potentially resulting in heart disease.
symptoms: High fever lasting for more than five days
Swelling and redness of the hands and feet
treatment: Close monitoring for heart complications such as aneurysms
preventive_measures: Early treatment with IVIG to prevent heart complications
Follow-up care to monitor heart health

name: Keratopathy
description: Keratopathy refers to diseases of the cornea, often leading to impaired vision. It may be caused by infections, injuries, or genetic conditions, and it can result in corneal scarring, vision loss, or blindness if not treated appropriately.
treatment: Antibiotic or antifungal treatments for infections
Use of eye lubricants or contact lenses for symptomatic relief
preventive_measures: Proper hygiene and care with contact lenses

name: Klinefelter Syndrome
description: Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic condition in which males have an extra X chromosome. It leads to developmental delays, infertility, and may cause physical features such as taller height, reduced muscle tone, and breast development.
preventive_measures: No known prevention, but early diagnosis can help manage symptoms

name: Kisspeptin Deficiency
description: Kisspeptin deficiency is a rare disorder affecting the regulation of puberty and reproductive function. It is caused by a deficiency in the kisspeptin protein, which plays a key role in stimulating the release of hormones necessary for puberty and fertility.
symptoms: Low levels of reproductive hormones (LH and FSH)
preventive_measures: Genetic counseling may help families with a history of the condition

name: Koschade's Syndrome
description: Koschade's syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that leads to developmental delays, intellectual disabilities, and in some cases, physical abnormalities. The exact cause and full clinical presentation are still under research.
preventive_measures: No known prevention, but early intervention can improve outcomes

name: Koplik Spots
description: Koplik spots are small, white lesions that appear on the inner lining of the cheeks, usually a few days before the onset of a measles rash. They are a characteristic sign of measles infection.
symptoms: Small, white spots inside the mouth, often near the molars
Red, blotchy skin rash that typically starts on the face
treatment: Vitamin A supplementation may help reduce severity

name: Koch's Postulates
description: Koch's postulates are a set of criteria used to establish a causative relationship between a microorganism and a disease. They were developed by Robert Koch and are a foundational principle in microbiology.
symptoms: No symptoms, as Koch's postulates are not a disease but a scientific framework
treatment: Not applicable, as Koch's postulates are used to prove causality of diseases
preventive_measures: Understanding and using Koch's postulates in disease research

name: Kleine-Levin Syndrome
description: Kleine-Levin syndrome is a rare sleep disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of excessive sleepiness, typically lasting days or weeks. During episodes, individuals may experience behavioral changes, such as irritability and confusion.
symptoms: Excessive sleep for 18-20 hours a day during episodes
Increased appetite or hypersexuality during episodes
preventive_measures: No known prevention, but early diagnosis can help manage symptoms

name: Keratocystic Odontogenic Tumor
description: Keratocystic odontogenic tumors are benign, cyst-like growths that form in the jawbones. They originate from the tissues involved in tooth development and can cause pain, swelling, and facial deformity if left untreated.
symptoms: Swelling or visible bulging in the jaw
treatment: Follow-up care to monitor for recurrence
preventive_measures: No known prevention, but regular dental check-ups can help detect issues early

name: Kallmann Syndrome
description: Kallmann syndrome is a genetic disorder that causes delayed or absent puberty and an impaired sense of smell (anosmia). It occurs due to a lack of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion, leading to insufficient production of sex hormones.
treatment: Fertility treatments for individuals with reproductive issues
preventive_measures: Genetic counseling for families with a history of Kallmann syndrome

name: Klippel-Feil Syndrome
description: Klippel-Feil syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the fusion of two or more vertebrae in the neck, leading to limited neck mobility and other skeletal abnormalities. It may also be associated with hearing loss or neurological issues.
symptoms: Possible hearing loss or neurological issues
treatment: Hearing aids or assistive devices for those with hearing loss
preventive_measures: No known prevention, but early diagnosis can help manage symptoms

name: Kidney Cancer
description: Kidney cancer, also known as renal cancer, is a malignancy that starts in the kidneys. The most common type is renal cell carcinoma. It can lead to symptoms like blood in the urine, pain, and unexplained weight loss.
symptoms: Pain in the back or side
Swelling in the ankles or legs
treatment: Targeted therapy or immunotherapy for advanced stages
Radiation or chemotherapy in some cases

name: Kearns-Sayre Syndrome
description: Kearns-Sayre syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects the mitochondria, leading to progressive muscle weakness, vision problems, and heart issues. It typically manifests before the age of 20.
preventive_measures: No known prevention, but early diagnosis can help manage symptoms

name: Kryptopyrrole Disorder
description: Kryptopyrrole disorder, also known as pyroluria, is a condition where there is an abnormal excretion of pyrroles, which can interfere with the body's absorption of vitamin B6 and zinc. It is often associated with symptoms like anxiety, depression, and other mental health issues.
treatment: Supplementation with vitamin B6 and zinc
Psychological therapy to manage mental health symptoms
preventive_measures: No known prevention, but supplementation can manage symptoms

name: Kennedy Disease
description: Kennedy disease, or spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy, is a genetic disorder that causes progressive muscle weakness, especially in the arms, legs, and face. It is caused by a mutation in the androgen receptor gene and typically affects males.
treatment: Physical therapy to maintain muscle function
Speech therapy for swallowing and speaking difficulties
preventive_measures: No known prevention, as it is genetically inherited

name: Kaliophiliasis
description: Kaliophiliasis is a rare condition associated with excessive potassium levels in the body, which can lead to symptoms such as muscle weakness, fatigue, and potentially life-threatening arrhythmias. It often occurs due to kidney dysfunction or excessive potassium intake.
treatment: Use of medications to manage potassium levels
preventive_measures: Managing kidney function and electrolyte balance

name: Lupus (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
description: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system attacks its own tissues. It can affect various organs including the skin, joints, kidneys, and heart, leading to inflammation, pain, and organ damage.

name: Leukemia
description: Leukemia is a type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow, causing the production of abnormal white blood cells. There are different types of leukemia, including acute and chronic forms, each with specific symptoms and treatments.
symptoms: Pain or tenderness in bones or joints
preventive_measures: No known prevention, but avoiding exposure to certain chemicals can reduce risk

name: Lung Cancer
description: Lung cancer is a type of cancer that begins in the lungs. It is often linked to smoking, although non-smokers can also develop the disease. The two main types are small-cell lung cancer and non-small-cell lung cancer.
preventive_measures: Screening for those at high risk

name: Liver Cirrhosis
description: Liver cirrhosis is a late stage of scarring (fibrosis) of the liver caused by many forms of liver diseases, such as chronic alcohol abuse or hepatitis. The scarring can impede liver function and lead to serious complications.
symptoms: Swelling in the legs and abdomen
treatment: Medications to treat underlying liver disease

name: Laryngitis
description: Laryngitis is the inflammation of the larynx (voice box), typically caused by viral infections, overuse of the voice, or irritants like smoke. It leads to hoarseness or loss of voice and is usually self-limiting.
preventive_measures: Washing hands regularly to prevent viral infections

name: Lyme Disease
description: Lyme disease is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted through tick bites. It commonly presents with a characteristic skin rash and can lead to joint, heart, and neurological complications if not treated.
preventive_measures: Wearing long sleeves and pants in tick-prone areas

name: Lymphoma
description: Lymphoma is a cancer of the lymphatic system, which is part of the immune system. The two main types are Hodgkin lymphoma and non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which have different symptoms and treatments.
preventive_measures: No known prevention, but early detection through regular check-ups can help improve outcomes

name: Lactose Intolerance
description: Lactose intolerance is the inability to digest lactose, a sugar found in milk and dairy products, due to a deficiency in lactase enzyme. It leads to gastrointestinal symptoms after consuming dairy products.
treatment: Avoiding dairy products or substituting with alternatives
preventive_measures: Avoidance of dairy products or use of lactase supplements

name: Legionnaire's Disease
description: Legionnaire's disease is a severe form of pneumonia caused by the Legionella bacteria, typically contracted through inhaling contaminated water vapor. It can cause serious respiratory illness, particularly in the elderly or those with weakened immune systems.
preventive_measures: Ensuring proper maintenance of water systems to prevent Legionella growth

name: Liver Disease
description: Liver disease encompasses a range of conditions affecting the liver, including hepatitis, fatty liver disease, cirrhosis, and liver cancer. Causes include alcohol abuse, viral infections, and metabolic conditions.
treatment: Treatment depends on the specific type of liver disease

name: Lipoma
description: A lipoma is a non-cancerous, fatty lump that grows under the skin. It is usually soft to the touch and slow-growing. Lipomas are typically harmless but may need removal if they cause discomfort or cosmetic concerns.
symptoms: Soft, movable lump under the skin
treatment: Steroid injections to shrink the lipoma
